botanical_details.potentially_harmful: Ingestion may cause severe discomfort, skin irritant. Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling
botanical_details.genus: Helleborus can be rhizomatous, herbaceous or semi-evergreen perennials forming a clump of pedate basal leaves, or evergreen with erect, leafy stems. Large, bowl-shaped flowers are borne in loose clusters in late winter or spring

how_to_grow.cultivation: Thrives in neutral to alkaline soils that are moist, fertile and humus-rich, in dappled shade. Provide shelter from strong, cold winds. Mulch annually in autumn. See hellebore cultivation
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by division of large clumps, after flowering in early spring, or in early autumn. As this plant is protected by Plant Breeders' Rights, any propagation should be for personal rather than commercial use.
how_to_grow.pruning: Remove faded or damaged foliage as the flowers appear
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to hellebore aphid, slugs, snails and vine weevil
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to hellebore leaf spot, and virus diseases including hellebore black death
